questions.text: Which of the following is not classified as a vasopressor among the sympathomimetic drugs?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: D) Dobutamine

 

EXPLANATION:

Dobutamine is a sympathomimetic drug that primarily acts on β1 adrenergic receptors, enhancing myocardial contractility and leading to increased cardiac output. It is primarily used as an inotrope to support cardiac function in heart failure rather than as a vasopressor.

 

Vasopressors:

Vasopressors

Uses

Selective α1 agonist

Phenylephrine

DOC:

  • Hypotension in aortic dissection surgeries
  • To treat hypotension as a vasopressor in spinal anesthesia
  • Mydriasis without cycloplegia

Midodrine

DOC: Postural hypotension

α+β receptors

Ephedrine

Hypotension in pregnancy.

Phenylephrine is the preferred agent for hypotension in pregnancy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a BMI of 33 kg/m², currently on olanzapine, seeks treatment for obesity. The physician discusses various pharmacological options. Which newer approved anti-obesity drug might be effective for this patient, considering her olanzapine therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Samidorphan

 

Explanation:

 

  • Olanzapine is an atypical antipsychotic that can cause weight gain, partly due to its interaction with opioid receptors in the brain, leading to increased appetite and food intake.
  • Samidorphan acts as an opioid receptor antagonist, blocking the effects of olanzapine on these receptors.
  • By counteracting the appetite-stimulating effects of olanzapine, samidorphan can potentially mitigate or reduce the weight gain associated with olanzapine therapy.

 

DRUG

MOA

STATUS

Liraglutide

GLP-1 receptor agonist that enhances satiety and slows gastric emptying, leading to weight loss

also used to treat type 2 diabetes

Approved

(Newer anti-obesity drug)

Samidorphan (Option C)

Opioid Receptor antagonist blocks the effects of olanzapine on the receptors and hence reduce the weight gain associated with Olanzapine

Approved

(Newer anti-obesity drug)

Setmelanotide

Selective agonist (activator) of the MC4R

  • Decreases appetite and increases the feeling of fullness (satiety)
  • Increases energy expenditure and metabolism
  • Promotes weight loss

(Newer anti-obesity drug)

Rimonabant

(Option A)

CB1 receptor antagonist; withdrawn due to psychiatric side effects.

Banned

Sibutramine (Option B)
  • Norepinephrine and serotonin reuptake inhibitor
  • Increase sympathetic activity by increasing amine levels in the brain.

Banned (due to cardiotoxicity)

(Withdrawn due to heart valve damage)

Fenfluramine (Option D)

questions.text: Which anti-obesity drugs work primarily by inhibiting pancreatic lipase, thereby reducing fat absorption in the gastrointestinal tract?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Orlistat

 

Explanation:

 

Category

Drugs

Inhibitors of Lipase

Orlistat (Option A)

Glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonist (Suppress appetite)

Liraglutide (Option C),

Sympathomimetic amine (Suppress appetite)

Amphetamine, Phentermine (Option B)

Stimulators of Lipase

Mirabegron

Opioid antagonists (Early satiety)

Topiramate, Naltrexone

Norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor (NDRI)

Bupropion (Option D)

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient with a history of depression is being treated with phenelzine, a monoamine oxidase inhibitor (MAOI). He presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe headache, palpitations, hypertension (blood pressure of 200/110 mmHg), and sweating. He reports consuming a large amount of aged cheese at a party earlier that evening.Which is the drug of choice for treating this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Phentolamine

 

Explanation: The patient is experiencing a hypertensive crisis, which is a known potential adverse effect of consuming foods containing tyramine (aged cheese) while taking MAOI (phenelzine).

 

CHEESE REACTION

Cause and Mechanism
  • The "cheese reaction" occurs when patients on MAOIs, such as phenelzine, consume foods high in tyramine (e.g., aged cheese).
  • Tyramine is normally metabolized by monoamine oxidase in the gut. However, MAOIs inhibit this enzyme, leading to high levels of tyramine.
  • Tyramine then enters the circulation and displaces norepinephrine from storage vesicles in adrenergic neurons, resulting in a sudden and excessive release of norepinephrine. This leads to severe hypertension, headache, palpitations, and other symptoms.

Treatment
  • Phentolamine, a non-specific reversible alpha-adrenergic blocker, is used to treat hypertensive emergencies caused by the cheese reaction.
  • It counteracts the excessive effects of norepinephrine by blocking alpha-adrenergic receptors, thereby lowering blood pressure.

questions.text: A 32-week pregnant female is suspected of having premature labour in the next few days. Which of the following drugs can be administered to prevent the same?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: B) Ritodrine

 

EXPLANATION:

 

Beta-2 adrenergic receptors are present in the uterus and smooth muscles, which relax them upon stimulation. Ritodrine (option B) is a selective beta-2 receptor agonist; hence, it can be used in this case to prevent premature labor by relaxing the uterus.

 

Options A, C, and D: Phenylephrine and methoxamine are alpha-adrenergic agonists and, hence, have no therapeutic benefit in premature labor. Isoprenaline is a non-specific beta-agonist, which causes side effects like tachycardia and palpitations when used as a tocolytic. It is less commonly employed now due to the availability of more selective beta-2 agonists that have fewer systemic side effects and are more effective.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought to the clinician due to difficulties in concentrating, impulsivity, and excessive fidgeting at home and in school. After a thorough assessment, the child is diagnosed with Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD). Which of the following medications would not be appropriate for the management of this child's symptoms?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: D) Lorazepam

 

EXPLANATION:

Lorazepam is a short-acting benzodiazepine that is not used to treat ADHD in children. It is used in insomnia, anxiety, and status epilepticus.

 

ADHD (Attention Deficit Hyperkinetic Disorder):

  • Mostly seen in children < 12 years.
  • Symptoms: Excessive motor activity, poor attention span (often fail at school), and impulsiveness.

 

Treatment of ADHD

Treatment of Choice
  • Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT)

Medical Management (if CBT is not effective)

Stimulants

Non-stimulants
  • Increase sympathetic activity.
  • Increase attention span and academic performance.
  • Cause hyperkinesia/tics.
  • Rapid onset and short duration.
  • Do not produce excessive movements/tics.
  • Delayed onset.
  • Less abuse potential.
  1. Methylphenidate: (Option A)
    1. Drug of choice
    2. Increase brain catecholamines.
  2. Dexamphetamine
  3. Lisdexamfetamine
  4. Dextroamphetamine
  1. Clonidine, Guanfacine: (Option C)
    1. Treatment in ADHD with tics
  2. Atomoxetine-SNRI

CNS STIMULANTS(methylphenidate)- not preferred in children less than 7 years of age instead atomoxetine is preferred here(antidepressant)
(Option B)

Side effects: Insomnia, abdominal pain, and weight loss.

Side effects: Insomnia, dry mouth and decreased appetite.

questions.text: A 19-year-old college student is brought to the emergency after ingesting amphetamine pills night before his final exam. On examination, he presents with agitation, hyperthermia, and severe hypertension. His pupils are dilated, and urine catheterisation reveals dark urine. Which of the following is next best step for this patient?
questions.solution:
This young student with signs of impulsiveness, hypertension, psychosis, and dark urine suggests amphetamine abuse due to exam performance pressure. Ammonium chloride is used to promote urinary drug excretion.

Amphetamine Poisoning:

  • Abused as “performance-enhancing drugs” among students and sportspersons.
  • Also called “rave party drugs”: Ecstasy/crystal/ methamphetamine/MDMA.
  • Sympathomimetic toxidrome: Increase heart rate, respiration, temperature, bowel sounds, sweating and pupil dilatation.
  • Triad: Sudden psychosis + Hypertension + Golden coloured urine.
  • Treatment:
    • Ammonium chloride turns urine pH acidic and causes forced diuresis of basic drugs like amphetamines.
    • Chlorpromazine: treats psychosis and hypertension through alpha-blocking action.

 

Intravenous sodium bicarbonate (Option A): is used for urinary alkalization in cases of salicylate poisoning (weak acid), which manifests as tinnitus, nausea, and vomiting.

Flumazenil (Option B): is used to reverse the effects of benzodiazepine poisoning, which appears with symptoms of CNS depression and impaired mental status.

Naloxone (Option D): is an opioid antagonist used to treat opioid overdoses, which present as pinpoint pupils and respiratory depression.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of excessive daytime sleepiness with sudden episodes of muscle weakness triggered by emotions. He reports that these symptoms have been significantly impacting his work performance. Which of the following is the drug of choice for treating this condition?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: B) Modafinil

EXPLANATION:

Modafinil:

  • Mechanism of action: Sympathetic CNS stimulant.
  • DOC for daytime sleepiness.
    • Occurs in:
      • OSA (obstructive sleep apnea): AR-modafinil is used
      • Narcolepsy.

Drugs approved for treatment of narcolepsy:

  1. Modafinil: sympathetic drug (reduces sleep)
  2. Tiprolisant/Pitolisant: H3 inverse agonist (increase wakefulness)
  3. Solriamfetol: Increase norepinephrine and dopamine (prevent sleepiness)
  4. Sodium γ-hydroxybutyrate (Na+-oxybate): Acts on GABA-B receptors.

 

Zolpidem (Option A): Atypical benzodiazepine, sedative-hypnotic used for insomnia, not for treating narcolepsy.

Lorazepam (Option C): ​​​​benzodiazepine used for anxiety and sleep disorders but not specifically for narcolepsy.

Propranolol (Option D): beta-blocker used to manage hypertension and anxiety.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of frequent urination and incontinence. She has been diagnosed with overactive bladder and has tried lifestyle modifications with limited success. Her physician decides to start medication for her symptoms; it will act on which of the following receptors?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: A) Beta-3-agonist- Mirabegron

 

EXPLANATION:

Beta-3 agonists (mirabegron) are the preferred medication for people with urine incontinence due to overactive bladder.

 

Beta-3-agonists:

Beta-3 receptors are located in the urinary bladder and white & brown adipose tissues.

 

Medication

Sibutramine

Mirabegron/Vebegron

Mechanism

Promote lipolysis
  • Relax detrusor muscles (increase nitric oxide).
  • Inhibits micturition

Use

Anti-obesity drug
  • Overactive bladder
  • Urinary incontinence

Side effects

Cardiotoxic
  • Increase blood pressure
  • UTI
  • CYP2D6 inhibitor

 

Beta-2-agonist – Terbutaline (Option B): Incorrect because it primarily acts on bronchial smooth muscle (used in asthma, preterm labor), not on the bladder.

 

Alpha-1-agonist – Phenylephrine (Option C): Incorrect because it can cause urinary retention by contracting the bladder neck and urethral sphincter, worsening OAB symptoms.

 

Alpha-1-antagonist – Tamsulosin (Option D): Incorrect as it is used for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) in men to relieve obstruction, not for detrusor overactivity in OAB.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male with a history of chronic sinusitis presents with complaints of persistent anosmia and nasal discharge. He used an over-the-counter nasal decongestant daily for the past three months. Which of the following statement is false regarding the treatment of the this condition?

A) It results from abruptly stopping the use of oxymetazoline nasal spray.

B) Long-term use of nasal decongestants is recommended to prevent this condition.

C) It is caused by ischemic atrophy of the nasal mucosa and olfactory nerve injury.

D) These drugs act on the alpha-adrenergic receptor, inducing vasodilation in the nose.

E) Oxymetazoline can also be used to treat cases of adult rosacea.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) 2 and 4

 

Explanation:
This patient's symptoms suggest rebound rhinorrhea as a result of Rhinitis Medicamentosa due to chronic nasal decongestant use.

 

Nasal decongestants:

  • MOA: Reduce rhinorrhea through 5ü1-receptor-mediated vasoconstriction in the nose. (Statement D)
  • Types:

Nasal drops

Oral medication
  • Xylometazoline
  • Naphazoline
  • Phenylephrine
  • Oxymetazoline (otrivin)
    • Also used to treat adult rosacea (Statement E)
  • Ephedrine
  • Pseudoephedrine
  • Phenylephrine

 

  • Rhinitis Medicamentosa:
    • Rebound rhinorrhea due to sudden stoppage after long-term use of nasal decongestants. (Statement A)

Treatment:

  • Short course of Glucocorticoids nasal spray
  • Avoid chronic nasal decongestant use (Statement B)

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the ophthalmologist for a routine eye examination. Which of the following drugs is most appropriate for pupillary dilation to assess the retina in this child?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Atropine

Explanation:

Atropine is the drug of choice for fundoscopy in children.

Mydriatics (dilatation of pupil):

Drug

Action

Duration and side effects

Atropine 1%
(Option B)
  • Drug of choice in children
  • Blocks muscarinic M3 receptors (overactive in children)
  • Cause circular muscle paralysis (Passive mydriasis)
  • Use: mydriasis, cycloplegia, keratitis, iridocyclitis
  • Long-acting ( >1 week)
  • Photosensitivity

Phenylephrine
2.5-10%
(Option A)
  • Drug of choice in adults
  • Stimulate alpha-1 receptors
  • Cause contraction of radial muscles (Active mydriasis)
  • Not used as cycloplegic
  • Last several hours
  • Increases blood pressure

Cyclopentolate
0.5-2%
(Option D)
  • Same as atropine
  • Use: iritis, uveitis, cycloplegia
  • Lasts one day
  • Transient behavioural abnormalities in children

Tropicamide
0.5-1%
  • Commonly used for office exams
  • Effect for several hours


Note: Pilocarpine (Option C) cause active miosis through stimulation of M3 receptors.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases can be treated with a drug that inhibits vesicular monoamine transporters (VMAT)?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Huntington’s chorea

EXPLANATION:

Movement disorders like Huntington’s chorea and tardive dyskinesia can be treated with drugs that inhibit vesicular monoamine transporters (VMAT).

  • As the name suggests, VMATs are transporters of monoamines, especially catecholamines (adrenaline, noradrenaline, and dopamine), within storage vesicles.
  • They are mainly of three types - VMAT 1, VMAT 2 & VAchT.

Centrally, this process mainly involves the release of dopamine, which is abnormal in movement disorders involving excessive dopaminergic activity.

Peripherally, this process occurs at the synaptic terminals, which are responsible for maintaining blood pressure; hence, these drugs were once used to manage hypertension.

Inhibitors: Tetrabenazine, deutetrabenazine, valbenazine

Inhibitor: Reserpine

These drugs selectively inhibit VMAT-1

This drug inhibits both VMAT-1 & VMAT-2

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Dobutamine is correct?

choices.text: It is administered as an I.M injection over the lateral aspect of the thigh usually.
It acts mainly on α adrenergic receptors, and is a weak β agonist.
Is an inotropic agent that increases cardiac output and is used in stress tests.
Cannot be used in cardiogenic shock without hypotension.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Is an inotropic agent that increases cardiac output and is used in stress tests.

Explanation:

Dobutamine:

Mechanism
  • It is a sympathomimetic amine.
  • It is mainly on β1 adrenergic receptors and is a weak α agonist. (Option B)
  • Administered at 2- 8 μg/kg/min i. v. infusion. (Option A)

Uses
  • Acute heart failure.
  • Cardiogenic shock without hypotension (DOC). (Option D)
  • Stress Echocardiography. (Option C)
  • Bridge therapy for heart transplant patients.

questions.text: You are an intern assisting in an operating theatre. During surgery, the patient suddenly goes into shock, showing signs of refractory hypotension. The surgeon asks you to prepare dopamine for infusion. Which of the following dosage ranges would be appropriate for the situation?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: C)10-50 mcg/kg/min

 

EXPLANATION:

Dosage Range

Clinical Use

Mechanism of Action

0-2 mcg/kg/min

Renal perfusion improvement (oliguria)

Stimulates D1 receptors primarily in renal vasculature, leading to vasodilation and increased renal blood flow

2-10 mcg/kg/min

Acute Congestive heart failure

Stimulates β1 receptors, leading to increased cardiac output and blood pressure

10-50 mcg/kg/min

Moderate to severe hypotension/shock

Predominantly acts on α1receptors, causing potent vasoconstriction

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding adrenaline?

choices.text: Adrenaline can be given in dilution with an anaesthetic in distal phalanges.
Adrenaline is contraindicated in patients with severe hypertension.
Adrenaline is commonly used in the management of anaphylactic shock.
Adrenaline is recommended for use in patients with Ventricular fibrillation.

questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: A) Adrenaline can be given in dilution with an anesthetic in distal phalanges.


 

EXPLANATION:

Adrenaline cannot be given in dilution with an anesthetic in distal phalanges because, when used in high concentration or in combination with local anesthetics, it can cause vasoconstriction, leading to decreased blood supply, which may result in tissue necrosis, especially in areas with limited blood flow like the distal phalanges.

 

Adrenaline is contraindicated in patients with severe hypertension (Option B)

  • It can exacerbate hypertension by increasing heart rate and constricting blood vessels.
  • Therefore, it is generally contraindicated in patients with severe hypertension.

 

Adrenaline is commonly used in the management of anaphylactic shock. The dose is 1:1,000 dilution, intramuscular injection (Option C)

  • It is the first-line treatment for anaphylactic shock because it can rapidly reverse severe allergic reactions by relieving airway constriction, increasing blood pressure, and reducing swelling and hives.

 

Adrenaline is recommended for use in patients with Ventricular fibrillation (Option D)

  • Adrenaline is recommended for use in patients with ventricular fibrillation as part of advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) protocols.
  • It helps to increase myocardial contractility and coronary perfusion pressure, thereby improving the chances of successful defibrillation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is brought to the emergency department by paramedics after a severe anaphylactic reaction to a bee sting. The patient is in obvious distress, with signs of airway swelling, difficulty breathing, and low blood pressure. The emergency team prepares to administer adrenaline to stabilise the patient. What is the correct dilution and route of administration for adrenaline in this situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1:1,000 dilution, intramuscular injection

 

Exolanation:

  • Adrenaline (epinephrine) is the first-line treatment for severe anaphylactic reactions.
  • In this scenario, the correct dilution of adrenaline for administration is 1:1,000.
  • In severe cases, the preferred route is an intramuscular injection (on the anterolateral aspect of the thigh); it ensures rapid absorption and onset of action, crucial in managing anaphylaxis.

 

Uses of epinephrine:

Condition

Use

Dilution/Concentration

Route of Administration

Anaphylaxis

First-line treatment for severe allergic reactions

1:1000 (1 mg/mL)
  • Intramuscular (IM)

Cardiac arrest

To restore cardiac rhythm and blood pressure

1:10,000 (0.1 mg/mL)
  • Intravenous (IV)
  • Intraosseous (IO)

Asthma

Treatment of acute severe asthma attacks

1:1000 (1 mg/mL)
  • Inhalation via nebulizer
  • Intramuscular (IM)
  • subcutaneous (SC)

Hypotension

To increase blood pressure

1:100,000 (0.01 mg/mL)
  • Intravenous (IV) infusion

Local anesthesia

Enhance duration and intensity of local anesthetic effect

1:200,000 to 1:100,000 (0.005 to 0.01 mg/mL)
  • Local injection

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency department after a car accident. He presents with hypotension, bradycardia, and signs of shock. The medical team decides to administer norepinephrine (NE) to stabilize his blood pressure. You are an intern monitoring the patient's blood pressure and heart rate continuously. Which of the following tracings most accurately represents the effect of norepinephrine on this patient's cardiovascular system?

choices.text: Increased systolic blood pressure with minimal change in diastolic blood pressure.
Increased systolic and diastolic blood pressure with increased heart rate.
Increased systolic and diastolic blood pressure with decreased heart rate.
Decreased systolic and diastolic blood pressure with increased heart rate.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Increased systolic and diastolic blood pressure with decreased heart rate

 

Explanation:

  • Norepinephrine (NE) is a sympathomimetic drug that acts on both α1 and β1 adrenergic receptors.
     
    • α1 receptors: NE induces vasoconstriction by binding to α1 receptors on vascular smooth muscle, increasing systemic vascular resistance (SVR), leading to elevated diastolic and systolic blood pressure.
       
    • β1 receptors: NE also has some effect on β1 receptors in the heart, which increases cardiac contractility and can raise systolic pressure.
       
  • The rise in blood pressure due to increased SVR and enhanced myocardial contractility activates the baroreceptor reflex.
     
    • This reflex leads to parasympathetic activation (via vagal stimulation) and bradycardia to counterbalance the elevated blood pressure, causing the heart rate to decrease.
       

Mechanism of Action:

Receptor

Effect

α1 adrenergic receptors

Vasoconstriction of arterioles and venules → increased systemic vascular resistance and diastolic blood pressure.

β1 adrenergic receptors

Increased heart rate (chronotropy) and increased contractility (inotropy), contributing to increased systolic blood pressure.

Baroreceptor reflex

Increased blood pressure triggers baroreceptor reflex leading to vagal stimulation and reflex bradycardia to reduce heart rate.

 

Norepinephrine effects on cardiovascular system:

Parameter

Effect of Norepinephrine

Systolic BP

Increased (due to β1 → ↑ contractility & α1 → ↑ afterload)

Diastolic BP

Increased (due to α1 → ↑ peripheral resistance)

Heart rate

Decreased (reflex bradycardia via baroreceptor stimulation)

Total Peripheral Resistance

Increased (due to vasoconstriction)

Pulse pressure

May slightly increase or stay the same


 

Increased systolic BP with minimal change in diastolic BP (Option A):
Incorrect because NE increases both systolic and diastolic BP significantly through vasoconstriction.
 

Increased systolic and diastolic BP with increased heart rate (Option B):
Incorrect because the baroreceptor reflex induces bradycardia (decreased heart rate), not tachycardia.
 

Decreased systolic and diastolic BP with increased heart rate (Option D):
Incorrect because NE causes vasoconstriction, leading to increased blood pressure, not decreased.

questions.text:
Match the following conditions with the most appropriate drug of choice.


	
		
			 
			
			Condition
			
			 
			
			Drug of choice
			
		
		
			
			1
			
			
			Septic shock
			
			
			i
			
			
			Epinephrine
			
		
		
			
			2
			
			
			Malignant hypertension with end-organ damage
			
			
			ii
			
			
			Dopamine
			
		
		
			
			3
			
			
			Acute decompensated heart failure with oliguria
			
			
			iii
			
			
			Fenodolpam
			
		
		
			
			4
			
			
			Cardiac arrest
			
			
			iv
			
			
			Norepinephrine
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) 1-iv, 2-iii, 3-ii, 4-i

 

Explanation:

Condition

Drug of choice

Septic shock

Norepinephrine

Malignant hypertension with end-organ damage

Fenodolpam

Acute renal failure

Dopamine

Cardiac arrest

Epinephrine

 

Uses:

  • Norepinephrine acts on alpha1, alpha2, beta1
  • Epinephrine acts on alpha1, alpha2, beta1, beta2

Norepinephrine

Fenodolpam
  • It acts on both alpha and beta receptors.
  • DOC for cardiogenic shock with hypotension.
    • Stimulates ꞵ1 receptors and increases the force of contraction of the heart.
    • Stimulates 𝛼1 receptors and causes vasoconstriction (increase in BP).
  • It is a partial D1 agonist.
  • It is a rapidly acting vasodilator that should not be used for >48 hours.
  • It can be given for control of severe hypertension (malignant hypertension with end-organ damage).

Dopamine

Epinephrine
  • It acts on D1 and D2 receptors.
  • It acts on both alpha and beta receptors except ꞵ2.
  • Dose-dependent action.
    • Acute decompensated heart failure with oliguria.
    • Cardiogenic and septic shock.
  • It acts on all receptors with a weak action on ꞵ3 receptors.
  • Uses:
    • Anaphylactic shock.
    • Brittle asthma.
    • Cardiac arrest.
    • Along with local anesthetics.

 

Dopamine exhibits dose-dependent actions, its effects vary based on the concentration administered.

  1. Low Doses:
    • At this range, dopamine primarily stimulates dopaminergic receptors.
    • This leads to renal vasodilation, which can enhance renal blood flow and promote diuresis.
    • It may also cause vasodilation in other vascular beds.
  2. Moderate Doses:
    • At this dosage, dopamine starts to activate beta-1 adrenergic receptors in addition to dopaminergic receptors.
    • This results in increased heart rate and myocardial contractility, which can improve cardiac output.
  3. High Doses:
    • At higher doses, dopamine predominantly stimulates alpha-adrenergic receptors, leading to vasoconstriction.
    • This can increase systemic vascular resistance and blood pressure.

questions.text: β2 receptors are present in all of the following organs except?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Urinary bladder.

Explanation:

The Urinary bladder has β3 receptors.

β-receptors:

  • They are Gs-type G-protein-coupled receptors that activate adenylyl cyclase, increasing the levels of cyclic AMP.
  • The table below shows the various types of receptors.
 

β1

β2

β3

Location

Heart and JG cells.

Bronchi, blood vessels, uterus, liver, GIT, urinary tract, and eye.

Adipose tissue and detrusor muscle of the urinary bladder.

Effects on stimulation
  • ↑ Heart rate.
  • ↑ Conduction rate.
  • ↑ Force of contraction.
  • ↑ Renin release (↑ BP).
  • Tremors.
  • Hyperglycemia.
  • Bronchodilation.
  • Vasodilation.
  • Tocolysis.
  • Lipolysis.
  • Relaxation of the detrusor muscle.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with pheochromocytoma. Which drug can help improve the patient’s symptoms by inhibiting tyrosine hydroxylase?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Metyrosine

Explanation:

Metyrosine inhibits tyrosine hydroxylase, the rate-limiting enzyme in synthesizing catecholamines.

Synthesis of catecholamines:

Methyldopa (Option A): Methyl DOPA is a centrally acting sympatholytic and alpha 2 agonist. It acts by inhibiting DOPA decarboxylase, which reduces dopamine synthesis.

Clonidine (Option B): acts by stimulating the presynaptic alpha-2 adrenergic receptors thus inhibiting the release of catecholamines.

Phenoxybenzamine (Option D): Phenoxybenzamine is an irreversible non-selective alpha blocker, Phentolamine and Tolazoline are reversible non-selective alpha-blockers. They inhibit the alpha-adrenergic receptors by acting on the postsynaptic terminals in smooth muscles.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). He is prescribed tamsulosin. Which of the following receptors does this drug act on?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) α1A

EXPLANATION :

Tamsulosin is an α1A blocker used in the treatment of BPH. Tamsulosin addresses the dynamic component of BPH, whereas finasteride, a 5- alpha reductase inhibitor addresses the static component of the disease.

α-blockers can be classified as:

  • Non-selective blockers (used in the treatment of pheochromocytoma).
  • Selective α1 blockers: DOC in BPH with hypertension.
    • α1A blockers: DOC in BPH without hypertension.
    • α1B blockers: Used in the treatment of hypertension.
  • Selective α2 blockers.

Alpha receptors:

They are a type of adrenergic receptor (membrane-bound G-protein coupled receptors) that function primarily by increasing or decreasing the production of second messengers cAMP or IP3/DAG.

They are present in various locations, and the table below describes them.

α1 (Gq type of GPCR)

α1A

α1B (Option B)
  • Present in the iris and internal urethral sphincter (IUS).
  • Effects: Mydriasis & smooth muscle contraction.
  • Present in the blood vessels.
  • Causes vasoconstriction (increased BP).

α2 (Gi type of GPCR)

α2A (Presynaptic autoreceptor) 

(Option C)

α2B (Postsynaptic receptor)

α2C (Extrasynaptic receptor) (Option D)
  • Presynaptic autoreceptor (It is an inhibitory autoreceptor stimulated by norepinephrine and inhibits its own release).
  • Postsynaptic receptor.
  • Similar functions like α1 receptors.
  • Present in platelets and duodenum.
  • Effects: Decrease in insulin and platelet attachment.
